meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>samurai</radical> has come bearing <radical>forehead</radical>s and <radical>legs</radical> that he's trying to <kanji>sell</kanji>. He thought it was a waste to leave all his slain enemies on the battlefield, so he gathered up their foreheads and legs to sell on the black market for some extra cash. Hey, no judging! A samurai's gotta sell what a samurai's gotta sell, okay?

You find a <radical>cross</radical> in the <radical>mouth</radical> of <radical>Wolverine</radical>. What a strange <kanji>occurrence</kanji>. I guess he put it there, but why would he do such a <kanji>thing</kanji>? You ask him, but he says it's a personal <kanji>matter</kanji> of utmost secrecy.

A good <radical>leader</radical> can put the <radical>ground</radical>'s <radical>history</radical> to great <kanji>use</kanji>. You are a good leader. You have studied the ground and dirt of the earth your entire life. You know the history of the ground and you know how to use it to lead your people.

There's an <radical>eye</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical>, among some <radical>fins</radical>. What happened? You killed a fish, and now you you must hide the murder <kanji>tool</kanji>. Quick, hide the tool before someone finds out it was you.

Someone throws a <radical>cleat</radical> at your <radical>forehead</radical> while you sit on a <radical>stool</radical>. You must <kanji>accept</kanji> this. Then another guy cleats you in the forehead, but you remain on the stool and <kanji>receive</kanji> it without complaint. This is some kind of acceptance ritual for the most prestigious Spanish soccer club in the world. If a cleat to the forehead doesn't knock you off the stool, you'll receive an offer to join.
When everyone has <radical>grain</radical> in their <radical>mouth</radical>, you will have <kanji>peace</kanji>. That is the <kanji>Japanese style</kanji> of doing things.
A <radical>roof</radical> is <radical>correct</radical> only if you <kanji>determine</kanji> that it is.

Climb onto the <radical>roof</radical> in <radical>spring</radical> to see the <kanji>truth</kanji>. The world is waking back up from winter and revealing the <kanji>reality</kanji> of what it is all around you.

Take the <radical>moon</radical> <radical>stamp</radical> on the <radical>stool</radical> in front of you and use it on all of your <kanji>clothes</kanji>. Now even if you sell or lose a piece of <kanji>clothing</kanji>, you'll be able to find it again by checking for your special moon stamp.

If a <radical>tsunami</radical> is going to last an <radical>eternity</radical> you better learn how to <kanji>swim</kanji> now. We'll be under water for the rest of time and if you can't swim you're not gonna make it.

A <radical>cow</radical> with <radical>wing</radical>s is flying in the air. What a strange <kanji>thing</kanji>! You've heard of flying pigs before, but cows? This is a new and strange thing indeed! Cows with wings! What a silly thing.
The <radical>flowers</radical> have grown <radical>old</radical>, so they're <kanji>suffering</kanji>.

Sometimes <radical>life</radical> gives you a <radical>kick</radical>, and you have to <kanji>express</kanji> yourself to deal with it! How do you express yourself? On the <kanji>surface</kanji> (of your face)!

The <radical>clown</radical> <radical>building</radical> is over in that <kanji>part</kanji> of town. We keep the clown part as separate as we can from the rest of the normal people. In fact, the entire clown education <kanji>department</kanji> and their clown <kanji>club</kanji>s have to stay in their part, they can't come in ours.

You put a grain in your mouth and let it take a ride. This kanji has the same radicals as 和, but this time the grain is in your mouth, which is why there's little pieces of grain sticking out of the 口 part ;)

Under your <radical>roof</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> there are more <radical>mouth</radical>s to feed because you let <kanji>guest</kanji>s stay with you when it's cold. Some of them aren't family, so they have to pay to stay under your roof and get food. Those are <kanji>customer</kanji>s.

You plant a <radical>flag</radical> in the <radical>ground</radical>, marking your <radical>private</radical> patch of <radical>dirt</radical>. In this spot you raise a <kanji>roof</kanji>, then fill the space beneath it with some <kanji>shop</kanji>s and <kanji>store</kanji>s.
A <radical>yurt</radical>'s <radical>stool</radical> is always placed at certain <kanji>degree</kanji>s. The degrees change depending on specific <kanji>occurrence</kanji>s.

You need to get your <radical>fingers</radical> around a <radical>temple</radical> if you want to <kanji>hold</kanji> it. Is the temple too big? Hold smaller temples you can buy in the temple's souvenir shop.
Every <radical>rice paddy</radical> sits <radical>jammed in</radical> to the <kanji>world</kanji>.

Go to the <radical>tent</radical> and take the <radical>lantern</radical> from it, then we will be ready for <kanji>departure</kanji>. We can't leave the lantern inside of the tent; that's a fire hazard. We'd best take it with us before the departure. Don't you agree?

You need to look a <radical>tree</radical> in the <radical>eye</radical> to gain a <kanji>mutual</kanji> respect for each other. Stand up straight, look the tree directly in its eye(s). If it looks right back, you know things are mutual.

The <radical>eye</radical> of a <radical>lion</radical>, still <radical>small</radical> and curious, gazes upon the <kanji>prefecture</kanji> that will one day become his. He's a small lion, but once he grows up, everything reflected in his eye will be his prefecture to rule over.
A <radical>sheep</radical> that's <radical>big</radical> is a true <kanji>beauty</kanji>. Big is <kanji>beautiful</kanji>, and that's all the more true for sheep.

When you're in <radical>prison</radical>, whoever ends up with the <radical>shellfish</radical> will <kanji>lose</kanji>. It's the game all prisoners play. It's like keep away from the shellfish. And if you end up with the shellfish BZZZZTT that's it, you're the loser.
On its <radical>scooter</radical>, a creature with <radical>horns</radical> from <radical>heaven</radical> will take things you want to <kanji>send</kanji> there.
The <radical>heavy</radical> radical and the <kanji>heavy</kanji> kanji are the same.

You  <radical>say</radical> things around a  <radical>fire</radical>. In fact there are two  <radical>fire</radical>s, and you're <kanji>talk</kanji>ing with a group of people, all sitting around two nice campfires.

When a <radical>helicopter</radical> is piloted by a <radical>woman</radical>, it stirs an insatiable <kanji>need</kanji> in her. She doesn't know what it is. But she needs it. And that's why she's flying around looking for it!
The <radical>moon</radical> grants a <radical>gladiator</radical> its <radical>power</radical> so he will <kanji>win</kanji>! <kanji>Victory</kanji> will be his!
Your <radical>leader</radical> is very <radical>anti</radical>-everything, making it all <kanji>temporary</kanji>. You get a new shirt, "I'm anti shirts!" she yells, and out it goes.
What does your <radical>mama</radical> tell you to do in the <radical>street</radical>? Look before you cross! You gotta do it <kanji>beforehand</kanji>, or it could be too late.
There's a <radical>stand</radical>ing <radical>tree</radical> that you're taking an <radical>axe</radical> to. You're going to cut down this tree to let a <kanji>new</kanji> tree grow.
Your <radical>scooter</radical> is <radical>anti</radical> scoot. It doesn't want to run. So you have to <kanji>return</kanji> it.

The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>elephant</radical>s is so great, they put up an <kanji>image</kanji> or <kanji>statue</kanji> of him everywhere. Every house, every street corner — his image looks down on all the other elephants at all times.

The <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>tree</radical> <radical>leader</radical> is all about trying to <kanji>preserve</kanji> the trees. In fact, she <kanji>guarantee</kanji>s that she will preserve the trees if it's the last thing she does.

If you want to <radical>say</radical> something at a <radical>ceremony</radical> for <radical>construction</radical> workers you're going to have to <kanji>try</kanji> really hard. Construction is loud, so if you want to be heard you have to <kanji>attempt</kanji> to be louder than the drilling and smashing and digging and handing out of awards.
A <radical>horse</radical> and a <radical>squid</radical> are going to <kanji>test</kanji> you.
The <radical>compare</radical> radical and the <kanji>compare</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Huzzah!
The <radical>spicy</radical> radical and <kanji>spicy</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Hot!
